source_info.text:
【0】 Pumpkin
【1】 Pumpkin is a gourd of the genus Cucurbita and the family Cucurbitaceae .  It can refer to either species Cucurbita pepo or Cucurbita mixta, or possibly to a specific variety of either the species Cucurbita maxima or Cucurbita moschata.
【2】 # Description
【3】 Since some squash share the same botanical classifications as pumpkins, the names are frequently used interchangeably. In general, pumpkins have stems which are firmer, ridgid, pricker, have +/- a 5 degree angle, and squarer in shape than squash stems which are generally softer, more rounded, and more flared where joined to the fruit.
【4】 Pumpkins generally weigh 9–18 lbs (4–8 kg) with the largest (of the species c. maxima) capable of reaching over 75 lbs (34 kg) . The pumpkin varies greatly in shape, ranging from oblate through oblong. The rind is smooth and usually lightly ribbed .
【5】 Although pumpkins are usually orange or yellow  , some fruits are dark green, pale green, orange-yellow, white, red and gray.
【6】 Pumpkins are angiosperms, having both male and female flowers, the latter distinguished by the small ovary at the base of the petals.
【7】 These bright and colorful flowers have extremely short life spans, and may only open for as short a time as one day. Their orange color is due to containing massive amounts of lutein, alpha- and beta-carotene. These nutrients turn to vitamin A in the body.
【8】 # Taxonomy
【9】 Pumpkin is a fruit of the species Cucurbita pepo or Cucurbita mixta.  It can refer to a specific variety of the species Cucurbita maxima or Cucurbita moschata, which are all of the genus Cucurbita and the family Cucurbitaceae.
【10】 In Korea and Japan, the word translating to "pumpkin" is a slang term for an unattractive woman. In the American South and Midwest, however, the term "pumpkin" is sometimes used as an endearment.
【11】 # Distribution and Habitation
【12】 Although native to the Western hemisphere, pumpkins are cultivated in North America, continental Europe, Australia, New Zealand, India and some other countries. The pumpkin is the state fruit of New Hampshire.
【13】 # Ecology
【14】 ## Cultivation in the US
【15】 Pumpkins have historically been pollinated by the native squash bee Peponapis pruinosa, but this bee has declined, probably due to pesticide sensitivity, and today most commercial plantings are pollinated by honeybees. One hive per acre  Department of Agriculture.  If there are inadequate bees for pollination, gardeners often have to hand pollinate. Inadequately pollinated pumpkins usually start growing but abort before full development. An opportunistic fungus is  sometimes blamed for abortions.
【16】 ## Giant Pumpkins
【17】 Pumpkins are capable of growing extremely large with the proper attention and care. The world record pumpkin weighs 1689 lbs . The 2007 record pumpkin was grown in Rhode Island and weighed at the  Topsfield Fair GPC in Topsfield, Massachusetts . The growth of enormous pumpkins being cultivated by hybridizing their seeds.
【18】 The largest pumpkins are Cucurbita maxima.  They were culminated from the hubbard squash genotype, crossed with kabocha-pumpkin types by enthusiast farmers through intermittent effort since the early 1800s.  As such germplasm is commercially provocative, a U.S. legal right was granted for the rounder phenotypes, levying them as constituting a variety, with the appellation "Atlantic Giant."  Processually this phenotype graduated back into the public domain, except now it had the name Atlantic Giant on its record  USDA PVP # .
【19】 # Uses
【20】 ## Cooking
【21】 When ripe, the pumpkin is very versatile. It can be boiled, baked, or roasted. Often, it is made into various kinds of pie which is a traditional staple of the Canadian and American Thanksgiving holiday. Pumpkins that are still small and green may be eaten in the same way as the vegetable marrow/zucchini. Pumpkins can  be eaten mashed or incorporated into soup. If milk is poured into a pumpkin and then the pumpkin is baked, it can be made into a pudding. In the Middle East, pumpkin is used for sweet dishes; a well-known sweet delicacy is called halawa yaqtin. In South Asian countries like India, pumpkin is cooked with butter, sugar, and spices; this dish is called kadu ka halwa. In Australia, pumpkin is often roasted in conjunction with other vegetables. In Japan, small pumpkins are served in savory dishes, including tempura. In Thailand, small pumpkins are steamed with custard inside and served as a dessert. Finally, pumpkin can be used to flavor both alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverages.
【22】 ## Pumpkin seeds
【23】 The hulled or semi-hulled seeds of pumpkins can be roasted and eaten as a snack, similar to the sunflower seed. Pumpkin seeds can be prepared for eating by first separating them from the orange pumpkin flesh, then coating them in a generally salty sauce (Worcestershire sauce, for example), after which the seeds are distributed upon a baking sheet, and then cooked in an oven at a relatively low temperature for a long period of time.
【24】 Pumpkin seeds are a good source of iron, zinc, essential fatty acids, potassium, and magnesium. Pumpkin seeds may  promote prostate health since components in pumpkin seed oil appear to interrupt the triggering of prostate cell multiplication by testosterone and DHT. Removing the white hull of the pumpkin seed reveals an edible, green-colored seed inside that is commonly referred to as a pepita in North and South America.
【25】 One gram of pumpkin seed protein contains as much tryptophan as a full glass of milk . Multiplying the number of fruiting sections in a field pumpkin (C. pepo variety) by 16 gives roughly the number of seeds in the pumpkin (give or take 10 or so). Guessing the number of seeds in the pumpkin is a game sometimes played by children.
【26】 Austria is a well-known producer of pumpkin seed oil.
【27】 # Activities involving pumpkins
【28】 ## Halloween
【29】 Using pumpkins as lanterns during Halloween is based on an ancient Celtic custom brought to America by Irish immigrants. All Hallows Even was celebrated on 31 October and marked the New Year of the Celtic calendar year and the Festival of Samhain. On that night hollowed-out turnips, beets and rutabagas with candles inside them were placed on windowsills and porches to welcome home the spirits of deceased ancestors and ward off evil spirits and a restless soul called "Stingy Jack," hence the name "Jack-o-lantern".
【30】 On Halloween night, Linus Van Pelt of the comic strip Peanuts waits in a pumpkin patch for "the Great Pumpkin", a fictional pumpkin which had many of Santa Claus's characteristics. It seems, however, to exist only in his imagination.
【31】 ## Chucking
【32】 Pumpkin chucking is a competitive activity in which teams build various mechanical devices designed to throw a pumpkin as far as possible. Catapults, trebuchets, ballistas and air cannons are the most common mechanisms. Some pumpkin chuckers breed and grow special varieties of pumpkin under specialized conditions in order to improve the pumpkin's chances of surviving a throw.
【33】 ## Pumpkin festivals and competitions
【34】 Pumpkin growers often compete to see whose pumpkins are the most massive. Festivals are often dedicated to the pumpkin and these competitions.
【35】 Circleville, Ohio, holds a big festival each year, the Circleville Pumpkin Show.  Half Moon Bay, California, holds the annual Pumpkin and Arts Festival, drawing over 250,000 visitors each year and including the World Champion Pumpkin Weigh-Off.  Farmers from all over the west compete to determine who can grow the greatest gourd . The winning pumpkin regularly tops the scale at more than 1200 pounds. (The world record pumpkin in 2007 was grown by Joe Jutras in Topsfield, Massachusetts.) Morton, Illinois, the self-declared pumpkin capital of the world, has held a Pumpkin Festival since 1966. The town, where Nestlé's pumpkin packing plant is located (and where 90% of canned pumpkins eaten in the US are processed) carved and lit pumpkins in one place, a record which the town held for several years before losing it to Boston, Massachusetts in 2006. A large contributor of pumpkins to the festival is local Keene State College which hosts an event called "Pumpkin Lobotomy" on their main quad. Usually held the day before the festival itself, Pumpkin Lobotomy has the air of a large party, with the school providing pumpkins and carving instruments alike (though some students prefer to use their own) and music provided by college radio station, WKNH.

【0】 Carpometacarpal bossing
【1】 # Overview
【2】 Carpometacarpal bossing  is a condition in  the  small, immovable mass of bone called the carpometacarpal joint and occurs when this joint becomes swollen or bossed.  The carpometacarpal joint is usually found at the base of the second and third metacarpal bones at the point where they meet the small bones of the wrist. This condition can result in sensitivity in the immediate area and/or an unsightly bulge on the back of the hand.  In most cases, the boss does not result in any injury or further problems, but in some cases, the patient may feel pain, aching, or even possibly a slight lack of mobility in the wrist joint. Often, this condition will be mistaken for a ganglion cyst due to its location and external appearance.
【3】 A carpometacarpal boss may exist from birth or may be the result of a trauma or injury in the affected area.  There are  indications that those with careers involving repetitive movements in the hands and fingers may develop this condition.  Typically, this condition will begin to show itself in the 3rd or 4th decade.
【4】 - Second metacarpal bone
【5】 - Third metacarpal bone
【6】 # Footnotes
【7】 
【8】 B. Jagannath Kamath &, Praveen Bhardwaj. "Carpal Bossing With Trapezium-Trapezoid Fusion". . Retrieved 2008-06-15.

source_info.text:
【0】 Bundle of Kent
【1】 Synonyms and keywords: Accessory atrioventricular muscle bundle, Kent Bundle, Kent pathway
【2】 # Overview
【3】 Bundle of Kent is an accessory conducting pathway between the atria and the ventricle of the heart.
【4】 # Historical Perspective
【5】 Paladina and Kent were the first to describe the myocardial fibers connecting the atrial and ventricular myocardium in normal hearts.  In 1932, Holzmann and Scherf suggested that ventricular pre-excitation was possible through these muscular connections.  Later, Wood and his colleagues and subsequently Ohnell described the first anatomical pathways for these accessory atrioventricular connections.
【6】 # Pathophysiology
【7】 Bundle of Kent is an abnormal pathway present in a small percentage of the general population that results in a condition known as Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW).  The anatomic substrate is a band of myocytes that bridges the fibrous junction between the atrium and the ventricle.
【8】 # Conditions Involving Bundle of Kent
【9】 Problems arise when this pathway creates an electrical circuit that bypasses the AV node.  The AV node has rate-slowing electrical regulatory properties, whereas the pathway via the bundle of Kent does not.  When an aberrant electrical impulse travels through the Kent bundle, tachyarrhythmia ensues.
【10】 # Treatment
【11】 In order to treat persons with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, destruction of the bundle of Kent is accomplished by radiofrequency catheter ablation.  This procedure is performed almost exclusively by cardiac electrophysiologists.

【0】 Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD): assessment and management
【1】 This guideline covers how to identify the adults, young people and children with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) who have advanced liver fibrosis and are most at risk of further complications. It outlines the lifestyle changes and pharmacological treatments that can manage NAFLD and advanced liver fibrosis.
【2】 # Recommendations
【3】 People have the right to be involved in discussions and make informed decisions about their care, as described in NICE's information on making decisions about your care.
【4】 Making decisions using NICE guidelines explains how we use words to show the strength (or certainty) of our recommendations, and has information about prescribing medicines (including off-label use), professional guidelines, standards and laws (including on consent and mental capacity), and safeguarding.
【5】 At the time of publication (July , neither pioglitazone nor vitamin E had a UK marketing authorisation for the treatment of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The prescriber should follow relevant professional guidance, taking full responsibility for the decision. Informed consent should be obtained and documented.  the General Medical Council's Prescribing guidance: prescribing unlicensed medicines for further information.
【6】 # Assessment for NAFLD
【7】 ## Identifying NAFLD in higher-risk groups
【8】 Be aware that non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is more common in people who have:
【9】 type 2 diabetes or
【10】 metabolic syndrome.
【11】 Take an alcohol history to rule out alcohol-related liver disease.   NICE's guideline on cirrhosis.
【12】 Do not use routine liver blood tests to rule out NAFLD.
【13】 ## Diagnosing NAFLD in children and young people
【14】 Offer a liver ultrasound to test children and young people for NAFLD if they:
【15】 have type 2 diabetes or metabolic syndrome and
【16】 do not misuse alcohol.
【17】 Refer children with suspected NAFLD to a relevant paediatric specialist in hepatology in tertiary care.
【18】 Diagnose children and young people with NAFLD if:
【19】 ultrasound shows they have fatty liver and
【20】 -ther suspected causes of fatty liver have been ruled out.
【21】 Offer liver ultrasound to retest children and young people for NAFLD every 3 years if they:
【22】 have a normal ultrasound and
【23】 have type 2 diabetes or metabolic syndrome and
【24】 do not misuse alcohol.
【25】 # Assessment for advanced liver fibrosis in people with NAFLD
【26】 ## Identifying people with advanced liver fibrosis
【27】 Offer testing for advanced liver fibrosis to people with NAFLD.
【28】 Consider using the enhanced liver fibrosis (ELF) test in people who have been diagnosed with NAFLD to test for advanced liver fibrosis.
【29】 Do not use routine liver blood tests to assess for advanced liver fibrosis in people with NAFLD.
【30】 Diagnose people with advanced liver fibrosis if they have:
【31】 an ELF score of 10.51 or above and
【32】 NAFLD.
【33】 Refer adults and young people diagnosed with advanced liver fibrosis to a relevant specialist in hepatology.
【34】 Explain to people with an ELF score below 10.51 that:
【35】 they are unlikely to have advanced liver fibrosis and
【36】 reassessment for advanced liver fibrosis every 3 years for adults and every 2 years for children and young people is sufficient for regular monitoring and
【37】 no interim tests are needed.Give the person advice about lifestyle modifications they may be able to make  section 1..
【38】 Offer retesting for advanced liver fibrosis for people with an ELF score below 10.51:
【39】 every 3 years to adults
【40】 every 2 years to children and young people.
【41】 Consider using ELF for retesting people with advanced liver fibrosis.
【42】 ## Monitoring adults and young people over 16 for cirrhosis
【43】 Monitor adults and young people over 16 with NAFLD and advanced liver fibrosis for cirrhosis in line with NICE's guideline on cirrhosis.
【44】 ## Extra-hepatic conditions
【45】 Be aware that NAFLD is a risk factor for type 2 diabetes, hypertension and chronic kidney disease.
【46】 Be aware that in people with type 2 diabetes, NAFLD is a risk factor for atrial fibrillation, myocardial infarction, ischaemic stroke and death from cardiovascular causes.
【47】 ## Lifestyle modifications for NAFLD
【48】 Offer advice on physical activity and diet to people with NAFLD who are overweight or obese in line with NICE's guidelines on obesity and preventing excess weight gain.
【49】 Explain to people with NAFLD that there is some evidence that exercise reduces liver fat content.
【50】 Consider the lifestyle interventions in NICE's guideline on obesity for people with NAFLD regardless of their BMI.
【51】 Do not offer omega-3 fatty acids to adults with NAFLD because there is not enough evidence to recommend their use.
【52】 Explain to people with NAFLD who drink alcohol the importance of staying within the national recommended limits for alcohol consumption.
【53】 # People with NAFLD who are taking statins
【54】 Be aware that people with NAFLD who are taking statins should keep taking them.
【55】 Only consider stopping statins if liver enzyme levels double within 3 months of starting statins, including in people with abnormal baseline liver blood results.
【56】 # Pharmacological treatment
【57】 In July 2016, the use of pioglitazone and vitamin E in recommendations 1.4.1 to 1.4.5 was off label.
【58】 NICE's information on prescribing medicines.
【59】 In secondary or tertiary care settings only, consider pioglitazone or vitamin E for adults with advanced liver fibrosis, whether they have diabetes or not.
【60】 Before prescribing pioglitazoneor vitamin E to adults, take into account any comorbidities that they have and the risk of adverse events associated with these conditions.
【61】 When prescribing pioglitazone, exercise particular caution if the person is at high risk of the adverse effects of the drug. Be aware that:
【62】 pioglitazone is contraindicated in people with a history of heart failure, previous or active bladder cancer and uninvestigated macroscopic haematuria (visible red blood cells in the urine)
【63】 known risk factors for these conditions, including increased age, should be carefully evaluated before treatment: see the manufacturers' summaries of product characteristics for details.
【64】 In tertiary care settings only, consider vitamin E for children with advanced liver fibrosis, whether they have diabetes or not.
【65】 In secondary or tertiary care settings only, consider vitamin E for young people with advanced liver fibrosis, whether they have diabetes or not.
【66】 Offer to retest people with advanced liver fibrosis 2 years after they start a new pharmacological therapy to assess whether treatment is effective.
【67】 Consider using the ELF test to assess whether pharmacological therapy is effective.
【68】 If an adult's ELF test score has risen, stop either vitamin E or pioglitazone and consider switching to the other pharmacological therapy.
【69】 If a child or young person's ELF test score has risen, stop vitamin E.
【70】 # Terms used in this guideline
【71】 ## Advanced liver fibrosis
【72】 A grade of F3 or above using the Kleiner (NASH-CRN) or the steatosis, activity and fibrosis (SAF) score. This is referred to as bridging fibrosis (the presence of fibrosis linking hepatic veins to portal tracts).
【73】 ## Adults, children and young people
【74】 These are defined as:
【75】 Children: over 1 year to under 16 years.
【76】 Young people: 16 to under 18.
【77】 Adults: 18 or older.
【78】 ## Metabolic syndrome
【79】 A group of chronic conditions that indicates increased cardiovascular risk. It includes central obesity (excessive abdominal fat), insulin resistance or type 2 diabetes, hypertension and dyslipidaemia.# Putting this guideline into practice
【80】 NICE has produced tools and resources to help you put this guideline into practice.
【81】 Putting recommendations into practice can take time. How long may vary from guideline to guideline, and depends on how much change in practice or services is needed. Implementing change is most effective when aligned with local priorities.
【82】 Changes recommended for clinical practice that can be done quickly – like changes in prescribing practice – should be shared quickly. This is because healthcare professionals should use guidelines to guide their work – as is required by professional regulating bodies such as the General Medical and Nursing and Midwifery Councils.
【83】 Changes should be implemented as soon as possible, unless there is a good reason for not doing so (for example, if it would be better value for money if a package of recommendations were all implemented at once).
【84】 Different organisations may need different approaches to implementation, depending on their size and function. Sometimes individual practitioners may be able to respond to recommendations to improve their practice more quickly than large organisations.
【85】 Here are some pointers to help organisations put NICE guidelines into practice:
【86】 . Raise awareness through routine communication channels, such as email or newsletters, regular meetings, internal staff briefings and other communications with all relevant partner organisations. Identify things staff can include in their own practice straight away.
【87】 . Identify a lead with an interest in the topic to champion the guideline and motivate others to support its use and make service changes, and to find out any significant issues locally.
【88】 . Carry out a baseline assessment against the recommendations to find out whether there are gaps in current service provision.
【89】 . Think about what data you need to measure improvement and plan how you will collect it. You may want to work with other health and social care organisations and specialist groups to compare current practice with the recommendations. This may  help identify local issues that will slow or prevent implementation.
【90】 . Develop an action plan, with the steps needed to put the guideline into practice, and make sure it is ready as soon as possible. Big, complex changes may take longer to implement, but some may be quick and easy to do. An action plan will help in both cases.
【91】 . For very big changes include milestones and a business case, which will set out additional costs, savings and possible areas for disinvestment. A small project group could develop the action plan. The group might include the guideline champion, a senior organisational sponsor, staff involved in the associated services, finance and information professionals.
【92】 . Implement the action plan with oversight from the lead and the project group. Big projects may  need project management support.
【93】 . Review and monitor how well the guideline is being implemented through the project group. Share progress with those involved in making improvements, as well as relevant boards and local partners.
【94】 NICE provides a comprehensive programme of support and resources to maximise uptake and use of evidence and guidance.  our into practice pages for more information.
【95】 Also see Leng G, Moore V, Abraham S, editors  Achieving high quality care – practical experience from NICE. Chichester: Wiley.# Context
【96】 Primary non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is an excess of fat in the liver (steatosis) that is not a result of excessive alcohol consumption or other secondary causes. These secondary causes include side effects of certain medications, hepatitis C virus infection and particular endocrine conditions. NAFLD ranges from hepatic steatosis, through inflammatory non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), to fibrosis or cirrhosis.
【97】 The prevalence of NAFLD in the general population is estimated at 20% to 30%. Around 2% to 3% of the population have NASH. NAFLD is more common in people who have type 2 diabetes or metabolic syndrome.
【98】 The prevalence of NAFLD is increasing, placing a greater burden on healthcare resources. The rate of progression of NAFLD is variable; being overweight and having diabetes are associated with an increased risk of progressive disease. The average age of people with NASH is 40 years to 50 years and for NASH-cirrhosis 50 years to 60 years. However the emerging epidemic of childhood obesity means that increasing numbers of younger people have NAFLD, with some prevalence studies showing that up to 38% of obese children have evidence of NAFLD. With NAFLD progressing through its spectrum even in childhood, the age that people develop significant liver disease is likely to fall and early diagnosis and management are therefore important at all ages. There is currently no licensed treatment for NAFLD. Guidance is needed for use in both primary and secondary care settings.# Recommendations for research
【99】 The guideline committee has made the following recommendations for research. The guideline committee's full set of research recommendations is detailed in the full guideline.
【100】 # Non-invasive tests for diagnosing NAFLD in adults
【101】 Which non-invasive tests are most accurate and cost-effective in identifying non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in adults with risk factors, type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome?
【102】 ## Why this is important
【103】 Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is present in over 50% of adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus or metabolic syndrome. Untreated it can progress to fibrosis, cirrhosis and hepatocellular cancer. In most patients NAFLD is asymptomatic and is only detected incidentally when liver blood tests or abdominal ultrasound are performed for some other reason. Even then, more than 80% of patients with NAFLD have normal routine liver blood tests. There is an urgent need for a simple, accessible, cost-effective, non-invasive test capable of case-finding NAFLD in the huge numbers of people at risk.
【104】 The 'gold standard' for diagnosis is liver biopsy. It is not feasible to perform liver biopsy in large numbers of at risk patients, so magnetic resonance based techniques are increasingly used as the comparison in studies assessing non-invasive tests for NAFLD. These demonstrate high diagnostic accuracy but are impractical or too expensive for large scale case finding.
【105】 # Non-invasive tests for diagnosing NASH
【106】 Which non-invasive tests most accurately identify non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in people with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)?
【107】 ## Why this is important
【108】 NASH develops in only a minority of people with NAFLD. It is thought to be the precursor of liver fibrosis, which is associated with morbidity and mortality. As a result, NASH has been the main target for treatment in NAFLD. This is because reducing the severity of NASH would reduce the risk of a person progressing to fibrosis and advanced liver disease. However, the only way to identify people with NASH is by performing an invasive liver biopsy which is impractical in view of its risks to health and cost. Given that between 20 and 30% of the population have NAFLD, it is important that we have a simple non-invasive method for determining which people have NASH. Then they can start treatment to reduce the risk of developing fibrosis and complications of end-stage liver disease.
【109】 # Non-invasive tests for diagnosing NAFLD and advanced liver fibrosis in children and young people
【110】 Which non-invasive tests most accurately diagnose NAFLD and advanced liver fibrosis in children and young people?
【111】 ## Why this is important
【112】 NAFLD has become the most common chronic liver disease in children and young people in industrialised countries, mainly as a result of obesity.
【113】 NAFLD is often suspected in children and young people with abnormal liver tests or evidence of fatty changes on ultrasound. However, the spectrum of NAFLD (from simple steatosis to steatohepatitis, fibrosis, cirrhosis and liver-related morbidity) can be present in the absence of abnormal liver tests. Early detection and assessment of severity of NAFLD would help identify potential silent progressive fatty liver disease.
【114】 Diagnostic practice varies and includes clinical, biochemical and radiographic tests. The evidence review showed that few diagnostic techniques have been assessed in children and young people. There is some evidence for ELF in diagnosing advanced liver fibrosis in children and young people with NAFLD, but only from 1 study. Further research is needed to confirm the most accurate tests in this group.
【115】 # Probiotic and prebiotic supplements
【116】 What is the clinical and cost effectiveness of probiotics or prebiotics to treat NAFLD in adults, young people and children?
【117】 ## Why this is important
【118】 NAFLD is the most common metabolic liver disease, occurring in approximately 30% of all adults, around 46% of obese people and around 53% of people with type 2 diabetes. Liver fat accumulation is the first stage of more serious chronic liver disease in NAFLD. A small body of evidence supports the use of probiotics in NAFLD but the data are inconclusive and high-quality double-blind randomised placebo-controlled trials are needed. The evidence from cross-sectional studies suggests associations between unfavourable disturbance in gut microbiota and obesity or type 2 diabetes, but there is very limited evidence on whether modifying the gut microbiota influences NAFLD.
【119】 # Pharmacological therapy for advanced liver fibrosis in children and young people
【120】 What is the clinical and cost effectiveness of pharmacological therapy in children and young people with advanced liver fibrosis?
【121】 ## Why this is important
【122】 Observational studies reported that up to 10% of children and young people diagnosed with NAFLD progress to advanced liver fibrosis and are at risk of developing advanced stages of liver disease. Pharmacological treatment (for example, pioglitazone or vitamin E) could prevent progression to advanced liver fibrosis or end-stage liver disease, as has been reported in a number of high quality studies in adults with confirmed NAFLD. There are insufficient data on the efficacy of similar pharmacological treatment in children and young people with NAFLD to make clear treatment recommendations.

source_info.text:
【0】 Postnatal care
【1】 This guideline covers the routine postnatal care that women and their babies should receive in the first 8 weeks after the birth. It includes the organisation and delivery of postnatal care, identifying and managing common and serious health problems in women and their babies, how to help parents form strong relationships with their babies, and baby feeding. The recommendations on emotional attachment and baby feeding  cover the antenatal period.
【2】 # Recommendations
【3】 People have the right to be involved in discussions and make informed decisions about their care, as described in NICE's information on making decisions about your care. Parents and carers have the right to be involved in planning and making decisions about their baby's health and care, and to be given information and support to enable them to do this, as set out in the NHS Constitution and summarised in NICE's information on making decisions about your care.
【4】 Making decisions using NICE guidelines explains how we use words to show the strength (or certainty) of our recommendations, and has information about prescribing medicines (including off‑label use), professional guidelines, standards and laws (including on consent and mental capacity), and safeguarding.
【5】 Please note that the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists has produced guidance on COVID-19 infection and pregnancy for all midwifery and obstetric services.
【6】 This guideline uses the term 'woman' or 'mother' and includes all people who have given birth, even if they may not identify as women or mothers. 'Woman' is generally used but in some instances, 'mother' is used when referring to her in relation to her baby.
【7】 This guideline uses the term 'partner' to refer to the woman's chosen supporter. This could be the baby's father, the woman's partner, a family member or friend, or anyone who the woman feels supported by or wishes to involve. The term 'parents' refers to those with the main responsibility for the care of a baby. This will often be the mother and the father, but many other family arrangements exist, including single parents.
【8】 # Organisation and delivery of postnatal care
【9】 ## Principles of care
【10】 When caring for a woman who has recently given birth, listen to her and be responsive to her needs and preferences. Also see the NICE guideline on patient experience in adult NHS services.
【11】 Be aware that the 2020 MBRRACE-UK reports on maternal and perinatal mortality showed that women and babies from some minority ethnic backgrounds and those who live in deprived areas have an increased risk of death and may need closer monitoring. The reports showed that:
【12】 compared with white women (8 per 100,, the risk of maternal death during pregnancy and up to 6 weeks after birth is:
【13】 times higher in black women (34 per 100,
【14】 times higher in mixed ethnicity women (25 per 100,
【15】 times higher in Asian women (15 per 100,000; does not include Chinese women)
【16】 the neonatal mortality rate is around 50% higher in black and Asian babies compared with white babies (17 compared with 25 per 10,
【17】 women living in the most deprived areas are more than 2.5 times more likely to die compared with women living in the least deprived areas (6 compared with 15 per 100,
【18】 the neonatal mortality rate increases according to the level of deprivation in the area the mother lives in, with almost twice as many babies dying in the most deprived areas compared with the least deprived areas (12 compared with 22 per 10,.
【19】 A woman may be supported by her partner in the postnatal period. Involve them according to the woman's wishes.
【20】 When caring for a baby, remember that those with parental responsibility have the right be involved in the baby's care, if they choose.
【21】 When giving information about postnatal care, use clear language and tailor the timing, content and delivery of information to the woman's needs and preferences. Information should support shared decision making and be:
【22】 provided face-to-face and supplemented by virtual discussions and written formats, for example, digital, printed, braille or Easy Read
【23】 -ffered throughout the woman's care
【24】 individualised and sensitive
【25】 supportive and respectful
【26】 evidence based and consistent
【27】 translated by an appropriate interpreter to overcome language barriers.For more guidance on communication, providing information (including different formats and languages) and shared decision making, see the NICE guidelines on patient experience in adult NHS services and shared decision making, and the NHS Accessible Information Standard.
【28】 Check that the woman understands the information she has been given, and how it relates to her. Provide regular opportunities for her to ask questions, and set aside enough time to discuss any concerns.
【29】 Follow the principles in the NICE guideline on pregnancy and complex social factors for women who may need additional support, for example:
【30】 women who misuse substances
【31】 recent migrants, asylum seekers or refugees, or women who have difficulty reading or speaking English
【32】 young women aged under 20
【33】 women who experience domestic abuse.
【34】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on principles of care .
【35】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review G: provision of information about the postnatal health of women.
【36】 Loading. Please wait.
【37】 ## Communication between healthcare professionals at transfer of care
【38】 Ensure that there is effective and prompt communication between healthcare professionals when women transfer between services, for example, from secondary to primary care, and from midwifery to health visitor care. This should include sharing relevant information about:
【39】 the pregnancy, birth, postnatal period and any complications
【40】 the plan of ongoing care, including any condition that needs long-term management
【41】 problems related to previous pregnancies that may be relevant to current care
【42】 previous or current mental health concerns
【43】 female genital mutilation (mother or previous child)
【44】 who has parental responsibility for the baby, if known
【45】 the woman's next of kin
【46】 safeguarding issues ( see the NICE guideline on domestic violence and abuse and the NICE guideline on child abuse and neglect)
【47】 concerns about the woman's health and care, raised by her, her partner or a healthcare professional
【48】 concerns about the baby's health and care, raised by the parents or a healthcare professional
【49】 the baby's feeding.
【50】 Midwifery services should ensure that:
【51】 the transfer of care from midwife to health visitor is clearly communicated between healthcare professionals and
【52】 the woman or the parents are informed about the transfer of care from midwife to health visitor.
【53】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on communication between healthcare professionals at transfer of care .
【54】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review B: information transfer.
【55】 Loading. Please wait.
【56】 ## Transfer to community care
【57】 Before transfer from the maternity unit to community care, or before the midwife leaves after a home birth:
【58】 assess the woman's health  recommendations 1.2.2 and 1.2.
【59】 assess the woman's bladder function by measuring the volume of the first void after giving birth
【60】 assess the baby's health (including physical inspection and observation)
【61】 if the baby has not passed meconium, advise the parents that if the baby does not do so within 24 hours of birth, they should seek advice from a healthcare professional ( see recommendation 1.3.
【62】 make sure there is a plan for feeding the baby, which should include observing at least 1 effective feed.
【63】 Before transfer from the maternity unit to community care, discuss the timing of transfer to community care with the woman, and ask her about her needs, preferences and support available.
【64】 When deciding on the timing of the transfer to community care, take into account the woman's preferences, the factors in recommendations 1.1.10 and 1.1.11 and any concerns, including any safeguarding issues ( see the NICE guideline on domestic violence and abuse).
【65】 Before transfer from the maternity unit to community care, or before the midwife leaves after a home birth, give women information about:
【66】 the postnatal period and what to expect
【67】 the importance of pelvic floor exercises  the NICE guideline on pelvic floor dysfunction)
【68】 what support is available (statutory and voluntary services)
【69】 who to contact if any concerns arise at different stages.
【70】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on transfer to community care .
【71】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review A: length of postpartum stay.
【72】 Loading. Please wait.
【73】 ## First midwife visit after transfer of care from the place of birth or after a home birth
【74】 Ensure that the first postnatal visit by a midwife takes place within 36 hours after transfer of care from the place of birth or after a home birth. The visit should be face-to-face and usually at the woman's home, depending on her circumstances and preferences.
【75】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendation and how it might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on first midwife visit after transfer of care from the place of birth or after a home birth .
【76】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review C: timing of first postnatal contact by midwife.
【77】 Loading. Please wait.
【78】 ## First health visitor visit
【79】 Consider arranging the first postnatal health visitor home visit to take place between 7 and 14 days after transfer of care from midwifery care so that the timing of postnatal contacts is evenly spread out.
【80】 If a woman did not receive an antenatal health visitor visit, consider arranging an additional early postnatal health visitor visit.
【81】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on first health visitor visit .
【82】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review D: timing of first postnatal contact by health visitor.
【83】 Loading. Please wait.
【84】 # Postnatal care of the woman
【85】 ## Assessment and care of the woman
【86】 At each postnatal contact, ask the woman about her general health and whether she has any concerns, and assess her general wellbeing. Discuss topics that may be affecting her daily life, and provide information, reassurance and further care as appropriate. Topics to discuss may inclu
【87】 the postnatal period and what to expect
【88】 symptoms and signs of potential postnatal mental health problems and how to seek help
【89】 symptoms and signs of potential postnatal physical problems and how to seek help
【90】 the importance of pelvic floor exercises, how to do them and when to seek help  the NICE guideline on pelvic floor dysfunction)
【91】 fatigue
【92】 factors such as nutrition and diet, physical activity, smoking, alcohol consumption and recreational drug use ( see the NICE guidelines on maternal and child nutrition, weight management before, during and after pregnancy, tobacco and the UK Chief Medical Officer's physical activity guidelines for women after birth)
【93】 contraception  the Faculty of Sexual & Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) guideline on contraception after pregnancy)
【94】 sexual intercourse
【95】 safeguarding concerns, including domestic abuse  the NICE guideline on domestic violence and abuse and the NICE guideline on child abuse and neglect).
【96】 At each postnatal contact, assess the woman's psychological and emotional wellbeing. Follow the recommendations on recognising mental health problems in pregnancy and the postnatal period and referral in the NICE guideline on antenatal and postnatal mental health. If there are concerns, arrange for further assessment and follow up.
【97】 At each postnatal contact by a midwife, assess the woman's physical health, including the following:
【98】 for all women:
【99】 symptoms and signs of infection
【100】 pain
【101】 vaginal discharge and bleeding  the section on postpartum bleeding)
【102】 bladder function
【103】 bowel function
【104】 nipple and breast discomfort and symptoms of inflammation
【105】 symptoms and signs of thromboembolism
【106】 symptoms and signs of anaemia
【107】 symptoms and signs of pre‑eclampsia
【108】 for women who have had a vaginal birth:
【109】 perineal healing  the section on perineal health)
【110】 for women who have had a caesarean section ( see the NICE guideline on caesarean birth):
【111】 wound healing
【112】 symptoms of wound infection.
【113】 At the first postnatal midwife contact, inform the woman that the following are symptoms or signs of potentially serious conditions, and she should seek medical advice without delay if any of these occur:
【114】 sudden or very heavy vaginal bleeding, or persistent or increased vaginal bleeding, which could indicate retained placental tissue or endometritis
【115】 abdominal, pelvic or perineal pain, fever, shivering, or vaginal discharge with an unpleasant smell, which could indicate infection
【116】 leg swelling and tenderness, or shortness of breath, which could indicate venous thromboembolism
【117】 chest pain, which could indicate venous thromboembolism or cardiac problems
【118】 persistent or severe headache, which could indicate hypertension, pre‑eclampsia, postdural-puncture headache, migraine, intracranial pathology or infection
【119】 worsening reddening and swelling of breasts persisting for more than 24 hours despite self-management, which could indicate mastitis
【120】 symptoms or signs of potentially serious conditions that do not respond to treatment.
【121】 At each postnatal contact, give the woman the opportunity to talk about her birth experience, and provide information about relevant support and birth reflection services, if appropriate.  the section on traumatic birth, stillbirth and miscarriage in the NICE guideline on antenatal and postnatal mental health and the NICE guideline on post-traumatic stress disorder.
【122】 All healthcare professionals should ensure appropriate referral if there are concerns about the woman's health.
【123】 At 6 to 8 weeks after the birth, a GP should:
【124】 carry out an assessment including the points in recommendations 1.2.1 to 1.2.5 and taking into account the time since the birth
【125】 respond to any concerns, which may include referral to specialist services in either secondary care or other healthcare services such as physiotherapy.
【126】 For guidance on care for women with symptoms or signs of sepsis, see the NICE guideline on sepsis. If the woman has confirmed or suspected puerperal sepsis, assess the baby for symptoms or signs of infection.
【127】 For postnatal care of women who have had hypertension or pre‑eclampsia in pregnancy, see the NICE guideline on hypertension in pregnancy, in particular:
【128】 postnatal investigation, monitoring and treatment:
【129】 for women with chronic hypertension
【130】 for women with gestational hypertension
【131】 for women with pre-eclampsia
【132】 antihypertensive treatment during the postnatal period, including when breastfeeding
【133】 advice and follow-up at transfer to community care.
【134】 For postnatal care of women with pre-existing diabetes or who had gestational diabetes, see the recommendations on postnatal care in the NICE guideline on diabetes in pregnancy.
【135】 For guidance on assessing the risk and preventing venous thromboembolism in women who have given birth, see the NICE guideline on venous thromboembolism and the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists' guideline on reducing the risk of venous thromboembolism during pregnancy and the puerperium.
【136】 For guidance on assessing and managing urinary incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women who have given birth, see:
【137】 the NICE guideline on urinary incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women
【138】 the NICE guideline on pelvic floor dysfunction.
【139】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on assessment and care of the woman .
【140】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in:
【141】 evidence review F: content of postnatal care contacts
【142】 evidence review H: tools for the clinical review of women
【143】 evidence review I: assessment of secondary postpartum haemorrhage
【144】 evidence review E: timing of comprehensive assessment.
【145】 Loading. Please wait.
【146】 ## Postpartum bleeding
【147】 Discuss with women what vaginal bleeding to expect after the birth (lochia), and advise women to seek medical advice if:
【148】 the vaginal bleeding is sudden or very heavy
【149】 the bleeding increases
【150】 they pass clots, placental tissue or membranes
【151】 they have symptoms of possible infection, such as abdominal, pelvic or perineal pain, fever, shivering, or vaginal bleeding or discharge has an unpleasant smell
【152】 they have concerns about vaginal bleeding after the birth.
【153】 If a women seeks medical advice about vaginal bleeding after the birth, assess the severity, and be aware of the risk factors for postpartum haemorrhage in the NICE guideline on intrapartum care for healthy women and babies. Also be aware of the following factors, which may worsen the consequences of secondary postpartum haemorrhage:
【154】 anaemia
【155】 weight of less than 50 kg at the first appointment with the midwife during pregnancy (booking appointment).
【156】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on postpartum bleeding .
【157】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review I: assessment of secondary postpartum haemorrhage.
【158】 Loading. Please wait.
【159】 ## Perineal health
【160】 At each postnatal contact, as part of assessing perineal wound healing, ask the woman if she has any concerns and ask about:
【161】 pain not resolving or worsening
【162】 increasing need for pain relief
【163】 discharge that has a strong or unpleasant smell
【164】 swelling
【165】 wound breakdown.
【166】 Advise the woman about the importance of good perineal hygiene, including daily showering of the perineum, frequent changing of sanitary pads, and hand washing before and after doing this.
【167】 Consider using a validated pain scale to monitor perineal pain.
【168】 If the woman or the healthcare professional has concerns about perineal healing or if the woman asks for reassurance, offer or arrange an examination of the perineum by a midwife or a doctor.
【169】 If needed, discuss available pain relief options, taking into account if the woman is breastfeeding.
【170】 If the perineal wound breaks down or there are ongoing healing concerns, refer the woman urgently to specialist maternity services (to be seen the same day in the case of a perineal wound breakdown).
【171】 Be aware that perineal pain that persists or gets worse within the first few weeks after the birth may be associated with symptoms of depression, long-term perineal pain, problems with daily functioning and psychosexual difficulties.
【172】 Be aware of the following risk factors for persistent postnatal perineal pain:
【173】 episiotomy, or labial or perineal tear
【174】 assisted vaginal birth
【175】 wound infection or breakdown
【176】 birth experienced as traumatic.
【177】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on perineal health .
【178】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review J: perineal pain and evidence review H: tools for the clinical review of women.
【179】 Loading. Please wait.
【180】 # Postnatal care of the baby
【181】 ## Assessment and care of the baby
【182】 At each postnatal contact, ask parents if they have any concerns about their baby's general wellbeing, feeding or development. Review the history and assess the baby's health, including physical inspection and observation. If there are any concerns, take appropriate further action.
【183】 Be aware that if the baby has not passed meconium within 24 hours of birth, this may indicate a serious disorder and requires medical advice.
【184】 Carry out a complete examination of the baby within 72 hours of the birth and at 6 to 8 weeks after the birth  the Public Health England newborn and infant physical examination  screening programme). This should include checking the baby's:
【185】 appearance, including colour, breathing, behaviour, activity and posture
【186】 head (including fontanelles), face, nose, mouth (including palate), ears, neck and general symmetry of head and facial features
【187】 eyes: opacities, red reflex and colour of sclera
【188】 neck and clavicles, limbs, hands, feet and digits; assess proportions and symmetry
【189】 heart: position, heart rate, rhythm and sounds, murmurs and femoral pulse volume
【190】 lungs: respiratory effort, rate and lung sounds
【191】 abdomen: assess shape and palpate to identify any organomegaly; check condition of umbilical cord
【192】 genitalia and anus: completeness and patency and undescended testes in boys
【193】 spine: inspect and palpate bony structures and check integrity of the skin
【194】 skin: colour and texture as well as any birthmarks or rashes
【195】 central nervous system: tone, behaviour, movements and posture; check newborn reflexes only if concerned
【196】 hips: symmetry of the limbs, Barlow and Ortolani's manoeuvres
【197】 cry: assess sound.
【198】 At 6 to 8 weeks, assess the baby's social smiling and visual fixing and following.
【199】 Measure weight and head circumference of babies in the first week and around 8 weeks, and at other times only if there are concerns. Plot the results on the growth chart.
【200】 For advice on identifying and managing jaundice, see the NICE guideline on jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days.
【201】 If there are concerns about the baby's growth, see the NICE guideline on faltering growth.
【202】 Carry out newborn blood spot screening in line with the NHS newborn blood spot screening programme.
【203】 Carry out newborn hearing screening in line with the NHS newborn hearing screening programme.
【204】 Give parents information about:
【205】 how to bathe their baby and care for their skin
【206】 care of the umbilical stump
【207】 feeding  recommendations on planning and supporting babies' feeding)
【208】 bonding and emotional attachment  recommendations on promoting emotional attachment)
【209】 how to recognise if the baby is unwell, and how to seek help  recommendations on symptoms and signs of illness in babies)
【210】 established guidance on safer sleeping (including recommendations on bed sharing)
【211】 maintaining a smoke-free environment for the baby   the NICE guideline on tobacco)
【212】 vitamin D supplements for babies in line with the NICE guideline on vitamin D supplement use
【213】 immunising the baby in line with Public Health England's routine childhood immunisations schedule.
【214】 Consider giving parents information about the Baby Check scoring system and how it may help them to decide whether to seek advice from a healthcare professional if they think their baby might be unwell.
【215】 Advise parents to seek advice from a healthcare professional if they think their baby is unwell, and to contact emergency services (call  if they think their baby is seriously ill.
【216】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on assessment and care of the baby .
【217】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review F: content of postnatal care contacts and evidence review L2: scoring systems for illness in babies.
【218】 Loading. Please wait.
【219】 ## Bed sharing
【220】 Discuss with parents safer practices for bed sharing, including:
【221】 making sure the baby sleeps on a firm, flat mattress, lying face up (rather than face down or on their side)
【222】 not sleeping on a sofa or chair with the baby
【223】 not having pillows or duvets near the baby
【224】 not having other children or pets in the bed when sharing a bed with a baby.
【225】 Strongly advise parents not to share a bed with their baby if their baby was low birth weight or if either parent:
【226】 has had 2 or more units of alcohol
【227】 smokes
【228】 has taken medicine that causes drowsiness
【229】 has used recreational drugs.
【230】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on bed sharing .
【231】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review M: benefits and harms of bed sharing and evidence review N: co-sleeping risk factors.
【232】 Loading. Please wait.
【233】 ## Promoting emotional attachment
【234】 Before and after the birth, discuss the importance of bonding and emotional attachment with parents, and the approaches that can help them to bond with their baby.
【235】 Encourage parents to value the time they spend with their baby as a way of promoting emotional attachment, including:
【236】 face-to-face interaction
【237】 skin-to-skin contact
【238】 responding appropriately to the baby's cues.
【239】 Discuss with parents the potentially challenging aspects of the postnatal period that may affect bonding and emotional attachment, including:
【240】 the woman's physical and emotional recovery from birth
【241】 experience of a traumatic birth or birth complications
【242】 fatigue and sleep deprivation
【243】 feeding concerns
【244】 demands of parenthood.
【245】 Recognise that additional support in bonding and emotional attachment may be needed by some parents who, for example:
【246】 have been through the care system
【247】 have experienced adverse childhood events
【248】 have experienced a traumatic birth
【249】 have complex psychosocial needs.

【253】 # Symptoms and signs of illness in babies
【254】 Listen carefully to parents' concerns about their baby's health and treat their concerns as an important indicator of possible serious illness in their baby.
【255】 Healthcare professionals should consider using the Baby Check scoring system:
【256】 to supplement the clinical assessment of babies for possible illness, particularly as part of a remote assessment and
【257】 as a communication aid in conversations with parents to help them describe the baby's condition.
【258】 Follow the recommendations in the NICE guideline on neonatal infection on:
【259】 assessing and managing the risk of early-onset neonatal infection after birth (within 72 hours of the birth)
【260】 risk factors for and clinical indicators of possible late-onset neonatal infection (more than 72 hours after the birth).
【261】 Be aware that fever may not be present in young babies with a serious infection.
【262】 If the baby has a fever, follow the recommendations in the NICE guideline on fever in under 5s.
【263】 If there are concerns about the baby's growth, follow the recommendations in the NICE guideline on faltering growth.
【264】 Be aware of the possible significance of a change in the baby's behaviour or signs, such as refusing feeds or a change in the level of responsiveness.
【265】 Be aware that the presence or absence of individual symptoms or signs may be of limited value in identifying or ruling out serious illness in a young baby.
【266】 Recognise the following as 'red flags' for serious illness in young babies:
【267】 appearing ill to a healthcare professional
【268】 appearing pale, ashen, mottled or blue (cyanosis)
【269】 unresponsive or unrousable
【270】 having a weak, abnormally high-pitched or continuous cry
【271】 abnormal breathing pattern, such as:
【272】 grunting respirations
【273】 increased respiratory rate (over 60 breaths/minute)
【274】 chest indrawing
【275】 temperature of 38°C or over or under 36°C
【276】 non-blanching rash
【277】 bulging fontanelle
【278】 neck stiffness
【279】 seizures
【280】 focal neurological signs
【281】 diarrhoea associated with dehydration
【282】 frequent forceful (projectile) vomiting
【283】 bilious vomiting (green or yellow-green vomit). the following sections in other NICE guidelines for more information:
【284】 fever in under 5s: clinical assessment of children with fever
【285】 neonatal infection: assessing and managing the risk of early-onset neonatal infection after birth and risk factors for and clinical indicators of possible late-onset neonatal infection
【286】 sepsis: identifying people with suspected sepsis
【287】 meningitis (bacterial) and meningococcal septicaemia in under 16s: symptoms, signs and initial assessment
【288】 gastroesophageal reflux disease (GORD) in children and young people: diagnosing and investigating GORD
【289】 diarrhoea and vomiting caused by gastroenteritis in under 5s: assessing dehydration and shock
【290】 urinary tract infection in under 16s: diagnosis.
【291】 If a baby is thought to be seriously unwell based on a 'red flag'  recommendation 1.4. or on an overall assessment of their condition, arrange an immediate assessment with an appropriate emergency service. If the baby's condition is immediately life-threatening, dial 999.
【292】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on symptoms and signs of illness in babies .
【293】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review L1: signs and symptoms of serious illness in babies and evidence review L2: scoring systems for illness in babies.

【295】 # Planning and supporting babies' feeding
【296】 ## General principles about babies' feeding
【297】 When discussing babies' feeding, follow the recommendations in the section on principles of care, and:
【298】 acknowledge the parents' emotional, social, financial and environmental concerns about feeding options
【299】 be respectful of parents' choices.
【300】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendation and how it might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on general principles about babies' feeding .

【303】 ## Giving information about breastfeeding
【304】 Before and after the birth, discuss breastfeeding and provide information and breastfeeding support  the section on supporting women to breastfeed). Topics to discuss may include   recommendation 1.5.:
【305】 nutritional benefits for the baby
【306】 health benefits for both the baby and the woman
【307】 how it can have benefits even if only done for a short time
【308】 how it can soothe and comfort the baby.
【309】 Give information about how the partner can support the woman to breastfeed, including:
【310】 the value of their involvement and support
【311】 how they can comfort and bond with the baby.
【312】 Inform women that vitamin D supplements are recommended for all breastfeeding women  the NICE guideline on vitamin D).
【313】 Inform women and their partners that under the Equality Act 2010, women have the right to breastfeed in 'any public space'.
【314】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on giving information about breastfeeding .

【320】 ## Role of the healthcare professional supporting breastfeeding
【321】 Healthcare professionals caring for women and babies in the postnatal period should know about:
【322】 breast milk production
【323】 signs of good attachment at the breast
【324】 effective milk transfer
【325】 how to encourage and support women with common breastfeeding problems
【326】 appropriate resources for safe medicine use and prescribing for breastfeeding women.
【327】 Encourage the woman to have early skin-to-skin contact with her baby so that breastfeeding can start when the baby and mother are ready.
【328】 Those providing breastfeeding support should:
【329】 be respectful of women's personal space, cultural influences, preferences and previous experience of infant feeding
【330】 balance the woman's preference for privacy to breastfeed and express milk in hospital with the need to carry out routine observations
【331】 -btain consent before offering physical assistance with breastfeeding
【332】 recognise the emotional impact of breastfeeding
【333】 give women the time, reassurance and encouragement they need to gain confidence in breastfeeding.
【334】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on the role of the healthcare professional supporting breastfeeding .

【337】 ## Supporting women to breastfeed
【338】 Give breastfeeding care that is tailored to the woman's individual needs and provides:
【339】 face-to-face support
【340】 written, digital or telephone information to supplement (but not replace) face-to-face support
【341】 continuity of carer
【342】 information about what to do and who to contact if she needs additional support
【343】 information for partners about breastfeeding and how best to support breastfeeding women, taking into account the woman's preferences about the partner's involvement
【344】 information about opportunities for peer support.
【345】 Make face-to-face breastfeeding support integral to the standard postnatal contacts for women who breastfeed. Continue this until breastfeeding is established and any problems have been addressed.
【346】 Be aware that younger women and women from a low income or disadvantaged background may need more support and encouragement to start and continue breastfeeding, and that continuity of carer is particularly important for these women.
【347】 Provide information, advice and reassurance about breastfeeding, so women (and their partners) know what to expect, and when and how to seek help. Topics to discuss inclu
【348】 how milk is produced, how much is produced in the early stages, and the supply-and-demand nature of breastfeeding
【349】 responsive breastfeeding
【350】 how often babies typically need to feed and for how long, taking into account individual variation
【351】 feeding positions and how to help the baby attach to the breast
【352】 signs of effective feeding so the woman knows her baby is getting enough milk (it is not possible to overfeed a breastfed baby;  recommendation 1.5.
【353】 expressing breast milk (by hand or with a breast pump) as part of breastfeeding and how it can be useful; safe storage and preparation of expressed breast milk; and the dangers of 'prop' feeding
【354】 normal breast changes during pregnancy and after the birth
【355】 pain when breastfeeding and when to seek help
【356】 breastfeeding complications (for example, mastitis or breast abscess) and when to seek help
【357】 strategies to manage fatigue when breastfeeding
【358】 supplementary feeding with formula milk that is sometimes, but not commonly, clinically indicated ( see the NICE guideline on faltering growth)
【359】 how breastfeeding can affect the woman's body image and identity
【360】 that the information given may change as the baby grows
【361】 the possibility of relactation after a gap in breastfeeding
【362】 safe medicine use when breastfeeding.
【363】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on supporting women to breastfeed .

【369】 ## Assessing breastfeeding
【370】 A practitioner with skills and competencies in breastfeeding support should assess breastfeeding to identify and address any concerns.
【371】 As part of the breastfeeding assessment:
【372】 ask about:
【373】 any concerns the parents have about their baby's feeding
【374】 how often and how long the feeds are
【375】 rhythmic sucking and audible swallowing
【376】 if the baby is content after the feed
【377】 if the baby is waking up for feeds
【378】 the baby's weight gain or weight loss
【379】 the number of wet and dirty nappies
【380】 the condition of the woman's breasts and nipples
【381】 -bserve a feed within the first 24 hours after the birth, and at least 1 other feed within the first week.
【382】 If there are ongoing concerns, consider:
【383】 -bserving additional feeds
【384】 -ther actions, such as:
【385】 adjusting positioning and attachment to the breast
【386】 giving expressed milk
【387】 referring to additional support such as a lactation consultation or peer support
【388】 assessing for tongue‑tie.
【389】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on assessing breastfeeding .
【390】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review R: tools for predicting breastfeeding difficulties.

【392】 ## Formula feeding
【393】 Before and after the birth, discuss formula feeding with parents who are considering or who need to formula feed, taking into account that babies may be partially formula fed alongside breastfeeding or expressed breast milk.
【394】 Information about formula feeding should inclu
【395】 the differences between breast milk and formula milk
【396】 that first infant formula is the only formula milk that babies need in the first year of life, unless there are specific medical needs
【397】 how to sterilise feeding equipment and prepare formula feeds safely, including a practical demonstration if needed
【398】 for women who are trying to establish breastfeeding and considering supplementing with formula feeding, the possible effects on breastfeeding success, and how to maintain adequate milk supply while supplementing.
【399】 For parents who formula feed:
【400】 have a one-to-one discussion about safe formula feeding
【401】 provide face-to-face support
【402】 provide written, digital or telephone information to supplement (but not replace) face-to-face support.
【403】 Face-to-face formula feeding support should inclu
【404】 advice about responsive bottle feeding and help to recognise feeding cues
【405】 -ffering to observe a feed
【406】 positions for holding a baby for bottle feeding and the dangers of 'prop' feeding
【407】 advice about how to pace bottle feeding and how to recognise signs that a baby has had enough milk (because it is possible to overfeed a formula-fed baby), and advice about ways other than feeding that can comfort and soothe the baby
【408】 how to bond with the baby when bottle feeding, through skin-to-skin contact, eye contact and the potential benefit of minimising the number of people regularly feeding the baby.
【409】 For parents who are thinking about supplementing breastfeeding with formula or changing from breastfeeding to formula feeding, support them to make an informed decision.
【410】 For a short explanation of why the committee made the recommendations and how they might affect practice, see the rationale and impact section on formula feeding .
【411】 Full details of the evidence and the committee's discussion are in evidence review T: formula feeding information and support.

【413】 ## Lactation suppression
【414】 Discuss lactation suppression with women if breastfeeding is not started or is stopped, breastfeeding is contraindicated for the baby or the woman, or in the event of the death of a baby. Follow the recommendations in the section on principles of care. Topics to discuss inclu
【415】 how the body produces milk, what happens when milk production stops, and how long it takes for milk production to stop
【416】 self-help advice, such as:
【417】 avoiding stimulating the breast
【418】 wearing a supportive bra
【419】 using ice packs
【420】 -ver-the-counter pain relief
【421】 sparingly expressing milk to ease engorgement
【422】 when to seek help
【423】 medicines that can be prescribed to suppress lactation
【424】 the advantages and disadvantages of the different methods of lactation suppression

【429】 # Terms used in this guideline
【430】 This section defines terms that have been used in a particular way for this guideline.
【431】 ## Bonding and emotional attachment
【432】 Bonding is the positive emotional and psychological connection that the parent develops with the baby.
【433】 Emotional attachment refers to the relationship between the baby and parent, driven by innate behaviour and which ensures the baby's proximity to the parent and safety. Its development is a complex and dynamic process dependent on sensitive and emotionally attuned parent interactions supporting healthy infant psychological and social development and a secure attachment. Babies form attachments with a variety of caregivers but the first, and usually most significant of these, will be with the mother and/or father.
【434】 ## Continuity of carer
【435】 Better Births, a report by the National Maternity Review, defines continuity of carer as consistency in the midwifery team (between 4 and 8 individuals) that provides care for the woman and her baby throughout pregnancy, labour and the postnatal period. A named midwife coordinates the care and takes responsibility for ensuring the needs of the woman and her baby are met throughout the antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal periods.
【436】 For the purpose of this guideline, the definition of continuity of carer in the Better Births report has been adapted to include not just the midwifery team but any healthcare team involved in the care of the woman and her baby, including the health visitor team. It emphasises the importance of effective information transfer between the individuals within the team. Having continuity of carer means that a trusting relationship can be developed between the woman and the healthcare professional(s) who cares for her. For more information, see the NHS Implementing Better Births: continuity of carer.
【437】 ## Effective feed
【438】 In general, effective feeding includes the baby showing readiness to feed, rhythmic sucking, calmness during the feed and satisfactory weight gain. For a first feed at the breast or with a bottle, effective feeding is shown by the baby latching to the breast or drawing the teat into mouth when offered and showing some rhythmic sucking.
【439】 ## First infant formula
【440】 First infant formula or 'first milk' is the type of formula milk that is suitable for a baby from birth to 12 months.
【441】 ## Low birth weight
【442】 A birth weight of less than 2,500 grams regardless of gestational age.
【443】 ## Nominal group technique
【444】 This is a structured method that uses the opinions of individuals within a group to reach a consensus. It involves anonymous voting with an opportunity to provide comments. Options with low agreement are eliminated and options with high agreement are retained. Using the comments that individuals provide, options with medium agreement are revised and then considered in a second round. For more information, see supplement 1 on methods.
【445】 ## Parental responsibility
【446】 the government definition of parental responsibility.
【447】 ## Parents
【448】 Parents are those with the main responsibility for the care of a baby. This will often be the mother and the father, but many other family arrangements exist, including single parents.
【449】 ## Partner
【450】 Partner refers to the woman's chosen supporter. This could be the baby's father, the woman's partner, a family member or friend, or anyone who the woman feels supported by or wishes to involve.
【451】 ## Prop feeding
【452】 When a baby's feeding bottle is propped against a pillow or other support, rather than the baby and the bottle being held when feeding.
【453】 ## Responsive feeding
【454】 Responsive feeding means feeding in response to the baby's cues. It recognises that feeds are not just for nutrition, but  for love, comfort and reassurance between the baby and mother (or parent in case of bottle feeding). Responsive breastfeeding  involves a mother responding to her own desire to feed for her comfort or convenience. Responsive bottle feeding involves holding the baby close, pacing the feeds and avoiding forcing the baby to finish the feed by recognising signs that the baby has had enough milk, and to reduce the risk of overfeeding. For more information, see the UNICEF Baby Friendly Initiative (BFI) information sheet on responsive feeding.# Recommendations for research
